results.creator_credit: Albert Soboul, Marguerite de la Mure, Victoria Mercanton and Co-operative Generale du Cinema Francais
results.brief_description: NARRATED IN FRENCH. NO ENGLISH SUBTITLES. Uses drawings and contemporary engravings by Daumier, Gauarni, Decamps and others to depict the period of the 1848 Revolution in France. Examines the causes for discontent as the monarchy totters, the fierce street fighting that precipitated its downfall, and finally the election of Louis Napoleon and the celebration of the new freedom - and the betrayal of that freedom.

results.title: 180 is max
results.creator_credit: Bill Pettigrew, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The twenty-third world championship match for builders of free-flight model aircraft, held at Goteborg, Sweden, in July 1971, in which a Canadian team competed. The film follows the successful flights and the failures, as competitors attempt to get their fragile handmade craft airborne by whatever means. (Award: Milan)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Pettigrew, Robert Verrall and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: 10 = Ten
results.creator_credit: Abbas Kiarostami, Marin Karmitz and MK2 Productions
results.brief_description: In Abbas Kiarostami’s “Ten”, ten vignettes, set in a car, are linked by the presence of the driver - a young mother, struggling to juggle the needs of her estranged young son and of her new marriage. Each conversation is, in essence, a reflection upon the human condition, and the fraught process of communication. Whilst passengers include the driver’s sister, a broken-hearted friend, an old woman and a prostitute, the most fascinating passenger is the woman’s son. The audience pays witness to their fraught and burdened relationship and the stubborn inability of each to simply hear the other. Using digital technology, Kiarostami’s minimalist approach presents a complex prism of the delicately balanced place of women in Iranian society.

results.title: 15' Zondergrond = 15' Metromania = 15 Metromania
results.creator_credit: Bart Van den Bempt, Karl Huysmans and Bert Hamelinck
results.brief_description: Bernd is the new security guard at the Metro underground. Just as he relaxes into the position, a stern boss dictates some impossible rules and young Bernd’s day goes from bad to worse. Drawing on the aesthetic of the surveillance industry, director Bart Van den Bempt parallels surveillance type images alongside the running plot with split screens. As Bernd, infatuation by a young woman, tracks her movements using the security cameras, we the audience tour the process of security camera surveillance. The film style and structure become bound to the processes of surveillance, whilst the process of surveillance informs the film structure (specifically the narrative and the editing style).

results.title: 147 break
results.creator_credit: Eric Harrison, Paul Doherty and Granada Television International
results.brief_description: Steve Davis became the first man in history to pot 15 reds, 15 blacks, plus all the colours in sequence under tournament conditions on television. This thrilling achievement is seen through Steve’s own eyes as he talks the viewer through the most difficult moments. Reminiscent of the “Pot Black” series and a must for snooker lovers.

results.title: 12,000 men
results.creator_credit: Martin Duckworth, Dennis Sawyer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This powerful documentary brings alive the brave story of Cape Breton’s union struggles in the coal and steel industries from the 1890s through the labour wars of the 1920s. The fight for decent wages and improved working conditions took on an urgency when the British Empire Steel Corporation, or BESCO, bought every single steel and coal company in Nova Scotia. When the Montreal-based company cut wages by a third, a long and bitter dispute began. The lockouts, picket lines and strikes were finally ended by brute force when provincial police and federal troops were sent in. The mine owners, however, were ultimately forced to recognize the union. This film combines vintage footage, photographs, drawings and interviews with men and women who were actually in the pits and on the front lines. These Cape Bretoners speak of the hardship and brief victories of the coal miners and their families. Photography by Martin Duckworth. Editing by Martin Duckworth and Shelagh Mackenzie. Sound by Patricia Kipping. Voice and narration by Kenzie MacNeil. (Awards: Yorkton)

results.title: 101 dalmatians
results.creator_credit: Stephen Herek, John Hughes, Ricardo Mestres, Great Oaks and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: This live-action adapted version of Dodie Smith’s classic children’s story will delight and amaze the whole family. Cruella De Vil (Glenn Close) is a woman with a passionate obsession for fur coats. Her quest is to have a coat made from the skin of the sweet dalmation pups owned by Anita and her husband Roger. The pups are kidnapped by two bumbling henchmen and Pongo and Perdita, the pups’ parents, enlist a canine army to execute a daring rescue. The special effects are outstanding as are the performances by an excellent cast, particularly Glenn Close. Co-starring Joely Richardson, Jeff Daniels, Joan Plowright and Hugh Laurie.

results.title: 100 years: the Australian story
results.creator_credit: Deborah Masters, Sue Spencer and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: A documentary of Australia, one of the world’s oldest democracies, this extensive and thorough series traces Australian political history. Themes of empire, independence, multiculturalism and indigenous Australia make up this enlightening series. Politicians, activists, experts and everyday Australians contributed to this powerful, educational documentary.

results.title: [Watching television]
results.brief_description: Short comic film made in 1958 by Graham Foster and friends to send to his relatives in New Zealand. Structured as ‘a mini sitcom’ the film features a group of friends engrossed in the act of watching television and has a voiceover by Foster. Features television advertising from the late 1950s. Companion piece to ‘A Kiwi in Exile’.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. Wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.
